results.title: Bacteria and Health
results.brief_description: Diagrams and experiments show that by taking simple precautions such as disinfecting and dressing wounds, washing hands in soapy water and being aware of the presence of bacteria, we can remain healthy. It also discusses the ways in which our bodies cope with bacteria, and whether they are useful or harmful to the body.

results.title: Bacteria
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Explains external and internal structures, manner of feeding, reproductive processes, classifications, and the ecological importance of bacteria. Also shows cell division and conjugation. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Backyard theatre: Michel Tremblay and Andre Brassard
results.brief_description: Playwright Michel Tremblay and director Andre Bassard have a talent for capturing the earthy wit and language of Montreal’s east-end working class neighbourhood, rendering them into live theatre described by some critics as “outrageously funny”. Both their vision and their style have had an important influence on other Quebec artists.

results.title: Backyard bugs
results.brief_description: Young Antonio is wondering how he will fill in time during his summer vacation, when he finds a pair of headphones in the grass. He puts them on and hears music which takes him on an adventure in his backyard, discovering bugs and the places they live. Students will learn to classify bugs by counting their legs and body parts. They will also be introduced to the functions of basic body parts and the phenomenon of metamorphosis. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Yale University
results.brief_description: A survey of the life among the Berber people of North Africa including aspects of their daily life such as their handcrafts, agricultural methods, customs and superstitions.

results.title: Backthenrightnowlateron
results.creator_credit: Queensland Performing Arts Centre, David Megarrity and Luke Monsour
results.brief_description:
Mixing interviews, images and tiny fictions, “Backthenrightnowlateron” is a funny and moving collection of children’s thoughts on their past, present and future.
The work is divided into three segments - Backthen, Rightnow, Lateron. Each segment features children from Class 2J, Yeronga State School, with their favourite toy sharing their thoughts with interviewer Georgia Seffrin, and a mini-film starring one of the toys - Chicky goes to nana’s house, Red Ted goes to England, Minotaur goes to war. Provides a wonderful and amusing insight into young children’s minds.
Developed from an original concept and commission by QPAC’s “Out of the Box” Festival of Early Childhood for the OOTB Symposium, September 2003.

results.title: Backstage
results.brief_description: A stunning and fascinating claymation short film presenting an honest and frank interview by phone with a strip dancer. The viewer is taken backstage to share Prisilla’s thoughts, feelings and impressions about life and experiences in this somewhat notorious and non-traditional industry.

results.title: Backs to the blast: an Australian nuclear story
results.brief_description: A history of the Uranium and nuclear industry in South Australia from 1910 to 1980, including archival footage and contemporary interviews with workers, scientists and politicians. Presents an analysis of the effects of uranium and its products and gives a detailed examination of Radium Hill, Port Pirie and Maralinga. Suitable for lower-mid Secondary students.

results.title: Background for reading: stories of Holland
results.brief_description: Views of Holland are used to provide a background to Dutch literature: views of windmills; canals; dairy farms and farm houses; fishing boats on the Zuyder Zee; old-fashioned costumes worn by the people; the dikes; tulip growing; views of the town of Leiden; Rembrandt’s studio and the old Church of St Peter’s.

results.title: Background for literature: The Lady of the lake
results.brief_description: Scottish scenes are used to illustrate excerpts from Sir Walter Scott’s poem “Lady of the lake”. The film, which includes a brief outline of the author’s life, is intended to demonstrate the concept that literature has its roots in actual places and people.
